Authors: Hidajat M., Supria, Luwinda F.A., Sanjaya H.
Title: Emotional Speech Classification Application Development Using Android Mobile Applications
Source title: Proceedings of 2019 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2019
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hidajat, M., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Supria, Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Luwinda, F.A., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sanjaya, H., Computer Science Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Customer Relationship Management (CRM) has become popular as it is believed to be able to improve company performance. One of the features of CRM are customer satisfaction level analyses. It is a verbal communication means of sending or receiving information. There are several intonations spoken during verbal communication that reflect the emotional state. Therefore, it can be used to get information regarding the level of customer satisfaction. Sound is one type of digital data that can be processed for an emotional state of classification. In this research, the authors decided to develop a mobile application that is integrated with machine learning to record a sound and classify it into a particular emotional state. This application is believed to be able to improve the user experience and simplify the installation to improve communication engagement. © 2019 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Android (operating system); Information management; Mobile computing; Public relations; Sales; Application development; component; Customer relationship management; formatting; Mobile applications; style; styling; Verbal communications; Customer satisfaction

Title: The roles of social media toward Indonesian's resilience after terrorist bombing in Jakarta 2016
Affiliations: Communication Department, Faculty of Computing and Media, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Computer Science Department, Faculty of Computing and Media, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Berewot, J., Communication Department, Faculty of Computing and Media, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Fibra, A., Communication Department, Faculty of Computing and Media, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Supria, Computer Science Department, Faculty of Computing and Media, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The emergence of social media has led to a new stage with wide range of usage to national resilience toward terrorism. During Jakarta attack, bombs and gunfire in January 14, 2016 many Indonesians defied terror with messages "We are not afraid" and "Unite Indonesia"They are using the hashtag #KamiTidakTakut, which can be translated as "We are not afraid", or hashtag #JakartaBerani, which means "Jakarta is brave". The next day, Indonesia regained national resilience by having normal activity. This research attempts to examine the roles of social media toward Indonesian's national resilience after the bombing. This research gathered data from social media such as Facebook, Path, Instagram and Twitter on posting, sharing posting, tweeting and re-tweeting during the event of a terrorist attack. Methodology approaches conducted in this research were qualitative study by questionnaire. This research offers insights into a broad range of views from users of social media about the use of social in building national resilience. The strength of the report is that it provides in-depth understanding of social media users and enhances government the use of social media for building national resilience. © Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Terrorism; Facebook; In-buildings; In-depth understanding; Indonesia; Methodology approaches; Qualitative study; Social media; Terrorist attacks; Social networking (online)
References: Antoci, A., Sabatini, F., Sodini, M., (2011) Bowling Alone but Tweeting Together: The Evolution of Human Interaction in the Social Networking Era, , (Rome, mimeo: Sapienza University of Rome); Buckley, M.E., Fawn, R., (2003) Global Responses to Terrorism: 9/11, Afghanistan, and beyond, , (London, Routledge); Dershowitz, A.M., (2002) Why Terrorism Works: Understanding the Threat, Responding to the Challenge, , (London: Yale University Press); Dufty, N., Using social media to build community disaster resilience (2012) The Australian Journal of Emergency Management, 27, pp. 40-45; Ellison, N.B., Steinfield, C., Lampe, C., The benefits of Facebook friends: Social capital and college students' use of online social network sites (2007) Journal of Computer-Mediated Communication, 12 (4), pp. 1143-1168; Manyena, S.B., The concept of resilience revisited (2006) Disasters Journal, 30, pp. 433-450; Norris, F.H., Stevens, S.P., Pfefferbaum, B., Wyche, K.F., Pfefferbaum, R.L., Community Resilience as a Metaphor, Theory, Set of Capacities, and Strategy for Disaster Readiness (2008) American Journal of Community Psychology, 41 (1-2), pp. 127-150; Rizza, C., Pereira, G.A., Building a resilient community through social network: Ethical considerations about the 2011 Genoa floods (2014) Proceedings of the 11th International ISCRAM Conference - University Park, Pennsylvania, USA, May 2014, , ed S R Hiltz, M S Pfaff, L Plotnick and P C Shih
